channel.title: Algorithm Problem
channel.description:
I just finished up this problem from my algorithms class homework a few hours ago and thought it would be neat to see if any of you can get it as well. For me at least it seemed really hard in the beginning, and I spent all class long thinking up ways that won't work, then when I got time to concentrate the solution came to me and it is as simple as it can be. Can you be the first to do it? :) ( You may need to know what [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation]Big O Notation[/url] is )
We can analyze space usage in the same way we analyze time usage. An O(1) bound would mean that the amount of memory required was always the same, regardless of n. (Or, at least, always the same once n hits some point.) An O(n) bound would mean that the amount of memory required grew linearly with n (perhaps an array of size n was used). An O(n^2) bound might imply a matrix was involved, etc.. Suppose we have an (unsorted) array of size n containing all numbers from 1 to n + 1 except one number. Give an algorithm that finds the missing number in O(n) time and O(1) extra space. (e.g. O(1) (constant) space once you discount the space required to store the input array.)
If no one comes up with a solution for awhile, I'll give a big hint that will help you crack it. But I am sure someone will post the solution before then. Goodluck. :|

item.title: Algorithm Problem
item.dc:creator: @super_OLDACCOUNT super_OLDACCOUNT
item.description:
@super_OLDACCOUNT wrote:

[quote=“Interdit, post:9, topic:178766”][quote author=seand link=topic=239788.msg2035100#msg2035100 date=1202287259]
an even more inefficient solution, but still O(n):

// int arr[n] that holds values from 1 to n+1 int newArr[n+2]; for(int i = 0; i < n; ++i) newArr[arr[i]] = 1; for(int i = 1; i < n + 2; ++i) if(newArr[i] != 1) return i;

zstars pointed out it doesn’t use O(1) space… oh well
[/quote]are you sean greasley???/ can u send me vids plz
[center] [/center][/quote]
yes, yes he is! ;(

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:14, topic:178766”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=239788.msg2053261#msg2053261 date=1203036433]

Maybe you mean ‘Integer’.

No, Interger…

        int[] array = { 6, 3, 1, 9, 5, 2, 7 };
        java.util.Arrays.sort(array);
        for(int i = 1; i < array.length; ++i)
            if(array[i] != 1 + array[i-1])
                System.out.println("MissingNumber = " + (array[i-1] + 1));

are we allowd to do this

[quote]MissingNumber = 4
MissingNumber = 8[/quote]
[/quote]the sort algorithm is probably O(N[sup]2[/sup]), so no, you cant do that you are also forcing the array to be sorted which is over complicating it[/quote]
i wondered as much about O(N[sup]2[/sup]),
it was just questioning, i didnt think i could.

thanks for clarification =]

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Less efficient but without using mathemathical formulas :

program prog2;

{$APPTYPE CONSOLE}

uses
  SysUtils;

const
  n = 7;
  arr : array [1..n] of Integer = (1, 2, 5, 3, 7, 4, 8);

var i : Integer;
    count : Integer;

begin

 count := n+1;
 for i := 1 to n do begin
   Inc(count, i);
   Dec(count, arr[i]);
 end;

 writeln('Missing number: ', count);
 readln;

end.

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Varek gets the cookie!

The thing that made me realize the answer is that in order for the algorithm to complete in O(n) time you can only look at each value once, also you need to store something about each variable in something fixed length. Now you know that you need to combine all variables to a single one and use math to find the answer!

Now remember from math class that the sum of 1 to n numbers is (n(n+1))/2 (in this particular problem, the added wrinkle is that n is actually n+1, since this is all numbers from 1 to n+1) and that gives us the answer

missingNumber = ((n+1)((n+1)+1))/2 - sumOfNumbersInArray;

simplified:

missingNumber = ((n+1)(n+2))/2 - sumOfNumbersInArray;

Which is what varek came up with (remember x/2 == .5*x)

Hopefully someone learned something from that ;D

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem
item.dc:creator: @varek varek
item.description:
@varek wrote:

S=0.5(n+1)(n+2) N=0 for i in series { N += i } M = S - N // Missing number
Would that work?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: February 05, 2008, 04:28:24 PM[/size][hr]Works for the set [1,2,4,5] if n=4

Read full topic
